descriptions.text: JSON-LD keyword to label the object with semantic tags
security definition names
Set of named security configurations(definitions only). Not actually applied unless names are used in a security name-value pair.

Indicates the semantic intention of performing the operation(s) described bythe form. For example, the Property interaction allows get and set operations.The protocol binding may contain a form for the get operation and a different form for theset operation. The op attribute indicates which form is for which and allows the client to selectthe correct form for the operation required. op can be assigned one or more interaction verb(s) representing a semantic intention of an operation.
Hypermedia controls that describe how an operation can be performed. Form is a  serializations of Protocol Bindings
Set of form hypermedia controls that describe how an operationcan be performed.Forms are serializations of Protocol Bindings

value.value: Human user, process and device identification and authentication

The ICS shall provide the capability to uniquely identify and authenticate all users (humans, processes and devices). This capability shall enforce such identification and authentication on all interfaces which provide access to the ICS to support segregation of duties and least privilege in accordance with applicable security policies and procedures.
The ICS shall provide the capability to support the management of accounts, including establishing, activating, modifying, disabling and removing accounts.

All users (human, processes and devices) need to be uniquely identified and authenticated for all access to the ICS. Authentication of the identity of these users should be accomplished by using methods such as passwords, tokens, biometrics or, in the case of multifactor authentication, some combination thereof. This requirement should be applied to both local and remote access to the ICS. In addition to identifying and authenticating all users at the ICS level (for example, at system logon), identification and authentication mechanisms should be employed at the application level, when necessary, to provide increased information security. Where human users function as a single group (such as, control room operators), user identification and authentication may be role-based, group-based or device-based. For some ICS, the capability for immediate operator interaction is critical. It is essential that local emergency actions for the ICS not be hampered by identification or authentication requirements. Access to these systems may be restricted by appropriate physical security mechanisms. In order to support such access control policies, the ICS verifies the identity of all users and ICS objects as a first step. In a second step, the permissions assigned to the identified user are enforced (see 5.3, SR 2.1  Authorization enforcement).

(1) The ICS shall provide the capability to employ multifactor authentication for access via an untrusted network (see 4.13, SR 1.11  Access via untrusted networks). NOTE Access via untrusted networks to ICS components is enabled only when necessary and approved.
(2) The ICS shall provide the capability to employ multifactor authentication for all system access.

The requirements for the four SAL levels that relate to SR 1.1 are:  SAL-C(IAC,system) 1: Not Selected  SAL-C(IAC,system) 2: SR 1.1 (1)  SAL-C(IAC,system) 3: SR 1.1 (1) (2)  SAL-C(IAC,system) 4: SR 1.1 (1) (2)

value.text: Elektrische Mess-, Steuer-, Regel- und Laborgeräte - EMV-Anforderungen - Teil 1: Allgemeine Anforderungen (IEC 61326-1:2012); Deutsche Fassung EN 61326-1:2013
Electrical equipment for measurement, control and laboratory use - EMC requirements - Part 1: General requirements (IEC 61326-1:2012); German version EN 61326-1:2013
Matériel électrique de mesure, de commande et de laboratoire - Exigences relatives à la CEM - Partie 1: Exigences générales

IEC 61326-1:2020 is available as <a href="https://webstore.iec.ch/publication/67782">IEC 61326-1:2020 RLV</a> which contains the International Standard and its Redline version, showing all                changes of the technical content compared to the previous edition.<br /> <br /> IEC 61326:2020 specifies requirements for immunity and emissions regarding electro¬magnetic compatibility (EMC) for electrical equipment, operating from a supply or battery of less than 1 000 V AC or 1 500 V DC or from the circuit being measured. Equipment intended for professional, industrial-process, industrial-manufacturing and educational use is covered by this part. It includes equipment and computing devices for<br /> - measurement and test;<br /> - control;<br /> - LABORATORY use;<br /> - accessories intended for use with the above (such as sample handling equipment),<br /> intended to be used in industrial and non-industrial locations.

IEC 61326-1:2020 est disponible sous forme de <a href="https://webstore.iec.ch/publication/67782">IEC 61326-1:2020 RLV</a> qui contient la Norme internationale et sa version Redline, illustrant les modifications du contenu technique depuis l'édition précédente.<br /> <br/> L’IEC 61326:2020 spécifie les exigences relatives à l'immunité et aux émissions concernant la compatibilité électromagnétique (CEM) pour les matériels électriques fonctionnant à partir d'une source d'alimentation ou d'une batterie inférieure à 1 000 V en courant alternatif ou 1 500 V en courant continu ou à partir du circuit mesuré. Elle concerne les matériels prévus pour un usage professionnel, pour les processus industriels et pour l'enseignement. Cela comprend les matériels et les dispositifs informatiques pour<br /> - le mesurage et les essais;<br /> - la commande;<br /> - les applications en LABORATOIRE;<br /> - les accessoires prévus pour être utilisés dans les cas susmentionnés (par exemple, matériel de manipulation d’échantillons),<br /> dans un usage en milieu industriel ou non industriel.
Human user, process and device identification and authentication - Requirement

The ICS shall provide the capability to uniquely identify and authenticate all users (humans, processes and devices). This capability shall enforce such identification and authentication on all interfaces which provide access to the ICS to support segregation of duties and least privilege in accordance with applicable security policies and procedures.
Human user, process and device identification and authentication - Rationale and supplemental guidance

All users (human, processes and devices) need to be uniquely identified and authenticated for all access to the ICS. Authentication of the identity of these users should be accomplished by using methods such as passwords, tokens, biometrics or, in the case of multifactor authentication, some combination thereof. This requirement should be applied to both local and remote access to the ICS. In addition to identifying and authenticating all users at the ICS level (for example, at system logon), identification and authentication mechanisms should be employed at the application level, when necessary, to provide increased information security. Where human users function as a single group (such as, control room operators), user identification and authentication may be role-based, group-based or device-based. For some ICS, the capability for immediate operator interaction is critical. It is essential that local emergency actions for the ICS not be hampered by identification or authentication requirements. Access to these systems may be restricted by appropriate physical security mechanisms. In order to support such access control policies, the ICS verifies the identity of all users and ICS objects as a first step. In a second step, the permissions assigned to the identified user are enforced (see 5.3, SR 2.1 – Authorization enforcement).
Human user, process and device identification and authentication - Requirement enhancements (1)

(1) The ICS shall provide the capability to employ multifactor authentication for access via an untrusted network (see 4.13, SR 1.11 – Access via untrusted networks). NOTE Access via untrusted networks to ICS components is enabled only when necessary and approved.
Human user, process and device identification and authentication - Requirement enhancements (2)
(2) The ICS shall provide the capability to employ multifactor authentication for all system access.
Human user, process and device identification and authentication - Security assurance levels

The requirements for the four SAL levels that relate to SR 1.1 are: - SAL-C(IAC,system) 1: Not Selected, - SAL-C(IAC,system) 2: SR 1.1 (1), - SAL-C(IAC,system) 3: SR 1.1 (1) (2) - SAL-C(IAC,system) 4: SR 1.1 (1) (2)
Account management - Requirement
The ICS shall provide the capability to support the management of accounts, including establishing, activating, modifying, disabling and removing accounts.
Account management - Rationale and supplemental guidance

Account management may include grouping of accounts (for example, individual, role-based, device-based and system), establishment of conditions for group membership and assignment of associated authorizations. In certain IACS instances, where individual accounts are determined to be  unnecessary from a risk-analysis and/or regulatory aspect, shared accounts are acceptable as long as adequate compensating controls (such as limited physical access) are in place and documented. Non-human user accounts (sometimes termed service accounts) that are utilized for processto-process communication (for example, a human-machine interface (HMI) connecting to a database) typically require different security policies and procedures from human user accounts.
Account management - Security assurance levels
The requirements for the four SAL levels that relate to SR 1.2 are: - SAL-C(IAC,system) 1: SR 1.2, - SAL-C(IAC,system) 2: SR 1.2, - SAL-C(IAC,system) 3: SR 1.2, - SAL-C(IAC,system) 4: SR 1.2
Strength of password-based authentication - Requirement

For ICS utilizing password-based authentication, the ICS shall provide the capability to enforce: a) configurable password strength based on minimum length and variety of character types; and b) password minimum and maximum lifetime restrictions for human users.
Strength of password-based authentication - Recommendation

User authentication based on a username and a secret password is a very commonly used mechanism. Many attacks on such mechanisms focus on guessing the password (for example, dictionary attacks or targeted social engineering) or breaking the cryptographic protection of the stored password representation (for example, using rainbow tables or bruteforcing a hash collision).  Increasing the size of the set of valid passwords by increasing the number of allowed characters makes such attacks more complex, but only if the increased set size is actually used (generally users would tend to not include special characters in a password as they are perceived harder to remember). Limiting the lifetime of a password decreases the window of opportunity for an attacker to breach a given password’s secrecy. In order to prevent users from circumventing this control by once changing their password to a new one and then immediately changing back to their original password, a minimum lifetime for a password is commonly enforced as well. This protection can be further enhanced by limiting the reuse of passwords (preventing small sets of alternating passwords), which further decreases the usefulness of a once-breached password. Extended protection beyond password based mechanisms can be achieved using multifactor authentication (see 4.3, SR 1.1 – Human user, process and device identification and authentication).
Strength of password-based authentication - Requirement enhancements (1)
(1) The ICS shall provide the capability to limit password reuse for a specified number of generations for human users.
Strength of password-based authentication - Requirement enhancements (1)
(2) The ICS shall provide the capability to enforce password minimum and maximum lifetime restrictions for process and device users.
Strength of password-based authentication - SAL

The requirements for the four SAL levels that relate to SR 1.5 are:- SAL-C(IAC,system) 1: Not Selected, - SAL-C(IAC,system) 2: SR 1.5, - SAL-C(IAC,system) 3: SR 1.5 (1), - SAL-C(IAC,system) 4: SR 1.5 (1) (2)

It includes equipment and computing devices for<br /> - measurement and test;<br /> - control;<br /> - LABORATORY use;<br /> - accessories intended for use with the above (such as sample handling equipment),<br /> intended to be used in industrial and non-industrial locations.

IEC 61326-1:2020 est disponible sous forme de <a href="https://webstore.iec.ch/publication/67782">IEC 61326-1:2020 RLV</a> qui contient la Norme internationale et sa version Redline, illustrant les modifications du contenu technique depuis l'édition précédente.<br /> <br/> L’IEC 61326:2020 spécifie les exigences relatives à l'immunité et aux émissions concernant la compatibilité électromagnétique (CEM) pour les matériels électriques fonctionnant à partir d'une source d'alimentation ou d'une batterie inférieure à 1 000 V en courant alternatif ou 1 500 V en courant continu ou à partir du circuit mesuré. Elle concerne les matériels prévus pour un usage professionnel, pour les processus industriels et pour l'enseignement. Cela comprend les matériels et les dispositifs informatiques pour<br /> - le mesurage et les essais;<br /> - la commande;<br /> - les applications en LABORATOIRE;<br /> - les accessoires prévus pour être utilisés dans les cas susmentionnés (par exemple, matériel de manipulation d’échantillons),<br /> dans un usage en milieu industriel ou non industriel.
Human user, process and device identification and authentication - Requirement

The ICS shall provide the capability to uniquely identify and authenticate all users (humans, processes and devices). This capability shall enforce such identification and authentication on all interfaces which provide access to the ICS to support segregation of duties and least privilege in accordance with applicable security policies and procedures.
Human user, process and device identification and authentication - Rationale and supplemental guidance

All users (human, processes and devices) need to be uniquely identified and authenticated for all access to the ICS. Authentication of the identity of these users should be accomplished by using methods such as passwords, tokens, biometrics or, in the case of multifactor authentication, some combination thereof. This requirement should be applied to both local and remote access to the ICS. In addition to identifying and authenticating all users at the ICS level (for example, at system logon), identification and authentication mechanisms should be employed at the application level, when necessary, to provide increased information security. Where human users function as a single group (such as, control room operators), user identification and authentication may be role-based, group-based or device-based. For some ICS, the capability for immediate operator interaction is critical. It is essential that local emergency actions for the ICS not be hampered by identification or authentication requirements. Access to these systems may be restricted by appropriate physical security mechanisms. In order to support such access control policies, the ICS verifies the identity of all users and ICS objects as a first step. In a second step, the permissions assigned to the identified user are enforced (see 5.3, SR 2.1 – Authorization enforcement).
Human user, process and device identification and authentication - Requirement enhancements (1)

(1) The ICS shall provide the capability to employ multifactor authentication for access via an untrusted network (see 4.13, SR 1.11 – Access via untrusted networks). NOTE Access via untrusted networks to ICS components is enabled only when necessary and approved.
Human user, process and device identification and authentication - Requirement enhancements (2)
(2) The ICS shall provide the capability to employ multifactor authentication for all system access.
Human user, process and device identification and authentication - Security assurance levels

The requirements for the four SAL levels that relate to SR 1.1 are: - SAL-C(IAC,system) 1: Not Selected, - SAL-C(IAC,system) 2: SR 1.1 (1), - SAL-C(IAC,system) 3: SR 1.1 (1) (2) - SAL-C(IAC,system) 4: SR 1.1 (1) (2)
Account management - Requirement
The ICS shall provide the capability to support the management of accounts, including establishing, activating, modifying, disabling and removing accounts.
Account management - Rationale and supplemental guidance

Account management may include grouping of accounts (for example, individual, role-based, device-based and system), establishment of conditions for group membership and assignment of associated authorizations. In certain IACS instances, where individual accounts are determined to be  unnecessary from a risk-analysis and/or regulatory aspect, shared accounts are acceptable as long as adequate compensating controls (such as limited physical access) are in place and documented. Non-human user accounts (sometimes termed service accounts) that are utilized for processto-process communication (for example, a human-machine interface (HMI) connecting to a database) typically require different security policies and procedures from human user accounts.
Account management - Security assurance levels
The requirements for the four SAL levels that relate to SR 1.2 are: - SAL-C(IAC,system) 1: SR 1.2, - SAL-C(IAC,system) 2: SR 1.2, - SAL-C(IAC,system) 3: SR 1.2, - SAL-C(IAC,system) 4: SR 1.2
Strength of password-based authentication - Requirement

For ICS utilizing password-based authentication, the ICS shall provide the capability to enforce: a) configurable password strength based on minimum length and variety of character types; and b) password minimum and maximum lifetime restrictions for human users.
Strength of password-based authentication - Recommendation

User authentication based on a username and a secret password is a very commonly used mechanism. Many attacks on such mechanisms focus on guessing the password (for example, dictionary attacks or targeted social engineering) or breaking the cryptographic protection of the stored password representation (for example, using rainbow tables or bruteforcing a hash collision).  Increasing the size of the set of valid passwords by increasing the number of allowed characters makes such attacks more complex, but only if the increased set size is actually used (generally users would tend to not include special characters in a password as they are perceived harder to remember). Limiting the lifetime of a password decreases the window of opportunity for an attacker to breach a given password’s secrecy. In order to prevent users from circumventing this control by once changing their password to a new one and then immediately changing back to their original password, a minimum lifetime for a password is commonly enforced as well. This protection can be further enhanced by limiting the reuse of passwords (preventing small sets of alternating passwords), which further decreases the usefulness of a once-breached password. Extended protection beyond password based mechanisms can be achieved using multifactor authentication (see 4.3, SR 1.1 – Human user, process and device identification and authentication).
Strength of password-based authentication - Requirement enhancements (1)
(1) The ICS shall provide the capability to limit password reuse for a specified number of generations for human users.
Strength of password-based authentication - Requirement enhancements (1)
(2) The ICS shall provide the capability to enforce password minimum and maximum lifetime restrictions for process and device users.
Strength of password-based authentication - SAL

The requirements for the four SAL levels that relate to SR 1.5 are:- SAL-C(IAC,system) 1: Not Selected, - SAL-C(IAC,system) 2: SR 1.5, - SAL-C(IAC,system) 3: SR 1.5 (1), - SAL-C(IAC,system) 4: SR 1.5 (1) (2)

value.value: Human user, process and device identification and authentication

The ICS shall provide the capability to uniquely identify and authenticate all users (humans, processes and devices). This capability shall enforce such identification and authentication on all interfaces which provide access to the ICS to support segregation of duties and least privilege in accordance with applicable security policies and procedures.
The ICS shall provide the capability to support the management of accounts, including establishing, activating, modifying, disabling and removing accounts.

All users (human, processes and devices) need to be uniquely identified and authenticated for all access to the ICS. Authentication of the identity of these users should be accomplished by using methods such as passwords, tokens, biometrics or, in the case of multifactor authentication, some combination thereof. This requirement should be applied to both local and remote access to the ICS. In addition to identifying and authenticating all users at the ICS level (for example, at system logon), identification and authentication mechanisms should be employed at the application level, when necessary, to provide increased information security. Where human users function as a single group (such as, control room operators), user identification and authentication may be role-based, group-based or device-based. For some ICS, the capability for immediate operator interaction is critical. It is essential that local emergency actions for the ICS not be hampered by identification or authentication requirements. Access to these systems may be restricted by appropriate physical security mechanisms. In order to support such access control policies, the ICS verifies the identity of all users and ICS objects as a first step. In a second step, the permissions assigned to the identified user are enforced (see 5.3, SR 2.1  Authorization enforcement).

(1) The ICS shall provide the capability to employ multifactor authentication for access via an untrusted network (see 4.13, SR 1.11  Access via untrusted networks). NOTE Access via untrusted networks to ICS components is enabled only when necessary and approved.
(2) The ICS shall provide the capability to employ multifactor authentication for all system access.

The requirements for the four SAL levels that relate to SR 1.1 are:  SAL-C(IAC,system) 1: Not Selected  SAL-C(IAC,system) 2: SR 1.1 (1)  SAL-C(IAC,system) 3: SR 1.1 (1) (2)  SAL-C(IAC,system) 4: SR 1.1 (1) (2)

value.text: Elektrische Mess-, Steuer-, Regel- und Laborgeräte - EMV-Anforderungen - Teil 1: Allgemeine Anforderungen (IEC 61326-1:2012); Deutsche Fassung EN 61326-1:2013
Electrical equipment for measurement, control and laboratory use - EMC requirements - Part 1: General requirements (IEC 61326-1:2012); German version EN 61326-1:2013
Matériel électrique de mesure, de commande et de laboratoire - Exigences relatives à la CEM - Partie 1: Exigences générales

IEC 61326-1:2020 is available as <a href="https://webstore.iec.ch/publication/67782">IEC 61326-1:2020 RLV</a> which contains the International Standard and its Redline version, showing all                changes of the technical content compared to the previous edition.<br /> <br /> IEC 61326:2020 specifies requirements for immunity and emissions regarding electro¬magnetic compatibility (EMC) for electrical equipment, operating from a supply or battery of less than 1 000 V AC or 1 500 V DC or from the circuit being measured. Equipment intended for professional, industrial-process, industrial-manufacturing and educational use is covered by this part. It includes equipment and computing devices for<br /> - measurement and test;<br /> - control;<br /> - LABORATORY use;<br /> - accessories intended for use with the above (such as sample handling equipment),<br /> intended to be used in industrial and non-industrial locations.
